captions.text:
Hi, I’m John Green, this is Crash Course
World History, and today we’re going to
talk about the Holy Roman Empire.

Which as Voltaire famously pointed out, was
not holy, or Roman, or an empire.

But the Holy Roman Empire can help us understand
world history, especially during the reign

of its most powerful emperor, the smart, and
sensible, and hard-working Charles Hapsburg,

known as Carlos I in Spain, and Charles V
in the rest of Europe.

So, lets frame it this way. In soccer, the World
Cup is like a pretty big deal, especially for me.
Mr Green? Mr Green? But I’m not even good at soccer
You’re actually not that bad Me From the Past, but the

only two things you put into your body are Wendy’s
and cigarette smoke. And that… it’s not

great for your athletic career.
In 2014, the final pitted Germany against

Argentina and if that game had been played
in 1550, both of those teams would’ve had

the same head of state.
The 2010 final between Spain and the Netherlands,

again the same head of state - Charles V.
Unfortunately, the 1550 World Cup had to be
postponed until after soccer was invented.

So, Charles V ruled one of the biggest empires
in history, behind only Chinggis Khan, Joseph

Stalin and Stalin’s successors in the Soviet
Union.

In addition to claiming to rule most of Europe,
during Charles’ lifetime, (1500-1558), one

of his dominions, Spain, laid claim to nearly
all of the New World outside of Brazil. And

a few of his subjects -- the miserable survivors
of the fleet of Ferdinand Magellan -- became

the first known humans to circumnavigate the
globe.

Under Charles, the template for the colonization
of the Americas and the Christianization and

treatment of its indigenous people was laid
down, and Charles gave his seal of approval

to the Jesuit Order to convert Asia. He underwrote
the first Mission settlements to California,

and began the process of turning the islands
known as the Philippines into Asia’s largest

Spanish-speaking country.
But he wasn’t just a conqueror. Charles

also hosted the Valladolid debates, the first-known
discussions of universal human rights -- and

he actively sought to end slavery for many.
Although, not for all, and he didn’t really

succeed in ending it for anyone.
Yet, for all that, Charles V isn’t known

as a giant of world history. I mean his realm,
the Holy Roman Empire, was ultimately, a failed

state, and his reign a bitter disappointment,
even to himself.

Trying to rule an empire stocked with rebellious
subjects including Martin Luther and with

territory in two hemispheres, Charles V managed
to totally bankrupt his realm and that was

kind of impressive.
Because he had access to the silver and gold

of the new world, the Renaissance banking
fortunes of Italy and the Netherlands, and

the military power of Spain.
In short, Charles V was to the Holy Roman
Empire what Screech is to the Saved by the Bell alumni.

By the time he died, crippled with gout and
malaria at the age of 58 - wait are we still

talking about Screech? No, apparently we’re
talking about Charles V now.

Anyway, the Holy Roman Empire was defaulting
on massive debts to its creditors.

So among historians, the debate over whether
Charles could have been a successful emperor

tends to break into two schools of thought.
One argues that the Holy Roman Empire was

doomed to fail largely because it lacked the
nationalism that powered the rising nation-states

like France and England.
But Voltaire was probably right, that the

Holy Roman Empire was doomed from birth. Over
it’s 1004-year-history, the Holy Roman Empire

never had the means of levying direct taxes,
or directly raising an army from its territory,

which nearly always included what are today
Eastern France, Luxembourg, Germany, Austria,

the Italian peninsula, and Czechoslovakia,
and at times stretched to the Netherlands,

and Belgium, Hungary, Croatia, Poland, and
western Ukraine.

Governing such a vast area is almost impossible,
especially when you have to have like you

know people on horses to deliver messages.
These days, even with the internet, governing

Europe isn’t that easy - Ask the European
Parliamentg how it’s going.

So the HRE began in 800 CE as a marriage between
the Germanic warlord, Charlemagne, and the

only sort of warlord-y Popes in Rome.
After the collapse of the Western Roman Empire

western Christendom was basically a flock
of rural warriors who reveled in trials by

combat, Christian conversion through combat,
and, just generally combat.

And Charlemagne shrewdly recognized that the
Church’s mainly literate hierarchy and command

of tradition were his best possible instruments
for governing his battle loving feudal lords.

So Charlemagne and Pope Leo III struck a deal;
Leo would bestow upon Charlemagne the authority

and tradition of the Caesars, while Charlemagne
acknowledged the Church’s spiritual superiority

over his secular power.
And the name for the agreement reflected the

terms of the deal. Holy, because the Church
wanted top billing, Roman, to give Charlemagne

maximum prestige among his feudal subjects,
and Empire, because they wanted it to be an

empire.
Here’s a lesson in romance from history:

marriages of convenience…. meh?
So the relationship between the popes and

the emperors grew a bit rocky over time. In
the centuries after Charlemagne, one European

warrior clan, the House of Hapsburg fought
to claim the Emperor’s throne, and to establish

dominance over the Papacy.
And one of the tactics used by the Hapsburgs

was to promote dynastic marriages between
Hapsburg cousins, thus keeping inheritances

within the family and out of the hands of
the Church.

This Hapsburg in-breeding worked politically,
but, over centuries, it brought out recessive

family genes for mental illness and -- most
famously -- these oversized lower jaws that

became Europe’s most-recognizable profile.
In short, in-breeding - great way to keep

money in the family, maybe not the best way
to keep A++ kings in the family.

The Papacy fought back and in 1356,the position
of Holy Roman Emperor was turned into an elected

position. Candidates for the crown henceforth
needed to win support from at least four of

seven “Electors.”
Now this didn’t prevent the Hapsburgs from

reclaiming the throne, but it did force the
family to pay fortunes in bribes and favors

to win it, because as always, money wins elections.
Charles was no exception and the bribes he

paid to secure the his position as Emperor
in 1521 meant that he started off his rule

in debt - which is never a great idea.
But wait, you say, now that he is Emperor

he can just tap into a loyal group of subjects,
who will be more than happy to pay tax increases

in order to pay off Charles’ debt.
But yeah, that’s not how the Holy Roman

Empire worked. All right, let’s get to know
this Emperor in the Thought Bubble

Charles’s parents came from two ambitious
dynasties. His mother, Juana, was the daughter

of Ferdinand and Isabella, whom you’ve probably
heard of. And from Juana, Charles laid claim

not only to Spain but to parts of Italy, including
Naples and Sicily, as well as what became

known as the Americas. Charles’s father
was the Duke of Burgundy, Phillip the Fair.

And through Philip, Charles could claim the German
lands of the Holy Roman Emperor, Maximilian

I, Phillip’s father.
So Charles’s existence was pretty much a

genetic engineering job designed to produce
a ruler of Spain and Germany. Only, Charles

was neither Spanish nor German himself. He
grew up in Belgium, in the dukedom of Burgundy,

which technically made him a French subject.
And ruling over so many disparate people was

a recipe for trouble. Like, German peasants
in Frisia had revolted against the empire

in 1515, but they weren’t nearly as troublesome
as the Germans living in towns. By the time

Charles bought his throne in 1521, German
merchants had come to think of themselves

as being guaranteed the rights to speak in
a parliament, to have a say in their taxes

and even to form their own militias.
Protestantism was also a big headache for

Charles, especially when Luther and his followers
claimed that they followed their consciences

in matters of religion rather than the emperor’s
will. Charles thought that he solved this

problem when he faced Luther at the Diet of
Worms in 1523, but that didn’t work out

quite as planned.
Thanks, Thought Bubble. So, at the Diet of

Worms Luther was so compelling when talking
about his faith that he became more popular

- not less.
And shortly thereafter he began his famous

German translation of the Bible.
So obviously, governing most of Europe was

just a tremendous difficulty for Charles V,
but he also had to be the ruler of all of

the Americas except for Brazil.
I can’t help but notice, Stan, that Brazil
is always the exception in the Americas.
And with the Spanish Conquistadors subjugation

of the the American Indians by the late 1530s,
Charles’s life got even worse or arguably

better.
Because he was richer and had more subjects

which is the point of being an emperor I guess.
So unlike most of the Spaniards in Spain’s

colonies, Charles actually showed some concern
for his native subjects, but he couldn’t

really do much.
Like in 1520, after receiving a steady stream

of complaints about how the native people
were being abused, Charles banned the granting

of new encomiendas and ordered his officials
to phase out the old ones.

And this worked … not at all. Hernan Cortes
and other leading conquistadors completely

ignored Charles orders and just kept doling
out encomiendas.

And then Charles sent new orders saying that
the Indians are “to live in liberty, as

our vassals in Castile live...if you have
given any Indians in encomienda to any Christians

you will remove them.”
Cortes responded, “The majority of the Spaniards

who come here are of low quality, violent,
and vicious.”

Well, I guess he was self-aware. Anyway, his
response amounted to - we could only get Spanish

people to come here if they have the right
to exploit other humans.

And then In 1526, Charles gave in and allowed
Cortes, and, later, Pizarro, to issue temporary

encomiendas to their men.
Now so far, Charles isn’t looking so good

in this story, so it might be useful to compare
his record to those of his contemporaries,

who, in theory, ruled more coherent and governable
states.

And it just so happens that Charles reigned
at the same time as two of Europe’s most

notable proto-nationalistic leaders, England’s
Henry VIII and France’s Francis I of France.

The bitterest rivalry was between Francis
and Charles, because Francis believed that

Charles, as the Duke of Burgundy, which is
in France, was his subject.

Charles, meanwhile, knew that Francis had
attempted to win the title of Holy Roman Emperor

himself, and had warned the electors that
Charles was an unfit and despotic man.

If we could just stop for a moment. Why on
earth would anyone fight to become the Holy

Roman Emperor.
The two monarchs fought four separate wars

against each other. And according to proponents
of nationalism, Francis should have had the

advantage, right. Because he had unchallenged
power of taxation in France, and a religious

class that was loyal to him, and a population,
or at least an elite, that all spoke French.

But Charles’s troops won every war. Not
only that, in the course of the wars Charles’

troops managed to take Francis himself hostage
at the siege of Pavia, and sack Rome in 1527,

ending the pope’s hope of becoming a real
player in secular politics, and, according

to some scholars, ending the Italian Renaissance.
Charles also fought a war against Suleiman

and the Ottomans, defeating them at Vienna,
although he wasn’t able to stop Suleiman

from consolidating his control over the formerly
Habsburg territory of Hungary.

But despite ruling this fractious, polyglot
empire rather than a compact national state,

Charles did okay for himself.
Well at least by some measures - by other

measure he was a total failure. Oh, it’s
time for the open letter.

But first, let’s see what’s in the globe
today. Oh, it’s all of my past romantic

relationships. An open letter to failure.
Dear failure, you’re so often in the eyes

of the beholder, like what looks like failure
at one point in your life can later look like

a wonderful success. I mean
Charles V had a lot of successes but ultimately

he viewed his reign as a terrible failure.
That’s why he eventually abdicated and retired

to a life of full time beer-drinking.
And then he split up his empire with his brother

getting the Holy Roman Empire and his son
getting Spain.

And that was probably marginally at least
a good thing for both the Holy Roman Empire

and Spain.
In short, failure almost no person is merely

a failure or even merely a success.
So enough with all these falsely constructed

dichotomies failure, they are complete failure.
Best wishes, John Green.

So, the story of Charles V reminds us of something
we learn again and again when studying World

History: that there are multiple sides to
every piece of history.

Yes, the Holy Roman Empire under Charles V
ceased to be Holy in the sense that it was

no longer 100% Catholic, it was never Roman
since Latin wasn’t among the many languages

spoken there…
And it wasn’t much of an empire because

it was too diverse and spread out for Charles
really to have the power of an emperor.

But as with most history, and many facebook
relationship statuses, and one Meryl Streep

movie - it’s complicated.
But perhaps the one concrete lesson we can

take away from the history of Charles V is
the benefits of acknowledging the limits of

one’s power. Charles never did.
His imperial motto was plus ultra. And that

means “further beyond,” but it could also
mean limitless. Charles sought to fuse Atlantic

and Central Europe into seamless whole on
a scale the size of today’s European Union.

He tried to stamp out the Protestant Reformation
and make his response, the

Catholic Counter-Reformation global.
He tried to create new policies in the New

World, while still defending old policies
in the Old World.

And by trying to be the most powerful Emperor
in the most powerful empire in the history

of the world he failed spectacularly.
There’s a lesson in that for all empires,

and all nation-states, and even all people.
Thanks for watching. I’ll see you next week.

Crash Course is filmed here in the Chad and
Stacey Emigholz studio in Indianapolis and

it’s made with the help of all of these
nice people and with your help.

Largely thanks to the support of our Subbable
subscribers. Subbable is a voluntary subscription

service that allows you to contribute directly
to Crash Course so we can keep it free for

everyone forever. Thank you for contributing,
thank you for watching, and as we say in my
hometown, “don’t forget to be awesome.”

title: Charles V and the Holy Roman Empire: Crash Course World History #219

comments.text:
Spain failed to make what today is the Philippines to become a 
Spanish-speaking colony due to its distance from Spain. Their colonial 
government is based in Mexico, those few assigned to the islands also came 
from the Americas, and education was only limited to landed elites who 
remained to be the only Spanish speakers until the beginning of the 20th 
century. English became the first successful colonial language in the 
country since public schools were implemented by the Americans and mass 
media boomed at this period.﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: Joe Garcia

comments.text:
+Ben Angel I would agree that those can be seen as different entities. 
However contemporaries didn't always make such distinct separations...
When Otto was crowned emperor he took on the same title as Charlemagne, 
actually his royal titles before were the same as well "Rex Francorum et 
Langobadorum". He clearly saw himself in the tradition of Charlemagne.
Medieval chroniclers always listed Charlemagne as their first emperor if 
you discount the Roman emperors of antiquity.

Having Otto the great as first "Holy Roman Emperor" is somewhat arbitrary 
and only makes sense from today's perspective.
comments.author: MacX1985

comments.text:
The Carolingian Empire was a whole other animal from the HRE (or the 
Heiliges Römisches Reich in German). It lasted from the coronation of 
Charlemagne in 800 to the death of Berengar, its last emperor, in 924. Otto 
the Great was the first crowned emperor of what would later be called the 
Holy Roman Empire in 962. As such, the Holy Roman Empire had only an 
844-year history. The Carolingian-founded Empire of the West were the 
forebearers of not only the Holy Roman Empire, but also France.

This would come out quite well if there were an episode about the so-called 
barbarian people who inherited the Roman Empire. Lots of interesting 
material to cover there (Goths, Lombards, Burgundians, Vandals, Huns, and 
even Franks, like Charlemagne).
comments.author: Ben Angel

comments.text:
The term "Holy Roman Emperor" actually was never used. It was "Roman 
Emperor" or "Emperor of the Romans". People nowadays say "Holy Roman 
Emperor" because it's convenient. There is no equivalent in German either.

It's only the empire that has been dubbed "holy" in the 12th century.

comments.author: Jordy Fourteen

comments.text:
I'm sure this has been said a ga-jillion times already here but none of 
Magellan's surviving crew were the first to circumnavigate the world. That 
honor belongs to a slave they originally had on board named Enrique of 
Malacca, who had already done a leg or two of the trip involuntarily 
earlier in his life, when he was first kidnapped from his island and sold 
into slavery.

The reason he almost never gets credit is because when Magellan landed at 
Malacca, he quite naturally jumped ship and escaped to his family and thus 
didn't end up in Europe, which is apparently where one *must* be to be 
counted for anything.﻿

comments.author: Sir George Severn

comments.text:
His most important realm was not the HRE, the Archduchy of Austria, the 
Duchy of Burgundy, or the Italian realms of Milan, Naples, Sicily or 
Sardinia. It was SPAIN. He was born in Ghent but lived most of his adult 
life in Spain. He died there and he allowed his son Felipe to grow up in 
Spain not the HRE﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: TheLoyalOfficer

comments.text: +MacX1985 Well I guess we are pretty much in agreement actually.
comments.author: TheLoyalOfficer

comments.text:
+TheLoyalOfficer „You see, though this is exactly my point.  They are 
referring to the title of "Emperor of the West" that I discussed earlier, 
NOT to Holy Roman Emperor per se. „

Well there is no „Holy Roman Emperor“ title. It's a made up title modern 
historians throw around. The historical title might have changed a bit over 
the time but it always meant the same thing.

„I think the most important aspect anyway is to look at what was meant by 
Charlemagne having the title in 800 and Otto getting it ca. 988 after 
Lechfeld. „

What was 988? Lechfeld was 955, his imperial coronation 962. I would say 
those two events are pretty much disconnected.
Otto got his imperial crown because he managed to attain the royal crown of 
Italy by overthrowing the old king Berengar and because he was the most 
powerful man of his time with whom the pope would want to arrange a deal so 
that he wouldn't be threatened by Italian nobles anymore.
Basically the same thing as Charlemagne.

„Otto was the first guy to TRULY shape the boundaries and culture of 
GERMANY, which was little more than an idea and dream at the time.“

Well, I would say his father Henry consolidated the East Frankish/German 
kingdom before him. Otto had to do it again and was more aggressive about 
it. His „Reichskirchensystem“ (imperial church system) and the victory at 
the Lechfeld established the German monarchy as a more stable institution 
for the time being.

Yeah, I would definitely see Otto's reign as a milestone in German history 
but the question was if him being the „Holy Roman Emperor“ was anything 
different than what Charlemagne established.
I don't know how you can argue that.

„The Carolingians were, and saw themselves more as, a universal empire. „

So did the Ottonians and some of the Salians. Frederick Barbarossa was all 
about being the universal emperor thus being so harsh about the lombard 
cities that dared to self-govern. I would argue that first during and after 
the interregnum the HRE would shrink more to its German nucleus.

„I also see your points about the connection through the word "Roman". 
 However, I think you may be weighing it a bit too much.

I don't think I am because of the Biblical prophecies and the reputation 
the emperors held by that title. Afterall, gaining the blessing by the pope 
was hard work every time.
The kings wouldn't have cherished it so much if it didn't hold as much 
meaning for them.

„ Europe had changed by 988.  Charlemagne was a distant memory and his 
empire long fallen to pieces.“

Well, yeah. Factually speaking, the Carolingian and the Ottonian realms 
were different entities. I think I cleared that point up earlier.
I'm talking about the title/function of „Holy Roman Emperor“ which I 
wouldn't suggest equating with the kingdoms the respective emperors reigned 
over.
Contemporaries didn't see a break in the continuation from Charlemagne to 
Otto I in that regard. Their kingdoms changed. The emperorship along with 
the „holy“ Roman empire couldn't.
comments.author: MacX1985

comments.text:
+MacX1985 You see, though this is exactly my point.  They are referring to 
the title of "Emperor of the West" that I discussed earlier, NOT to Holy 
Roman Emperor per se.

I think the most important aspect anyway is to look at what was meant by 
Charlemagne having the title in 800 and Otto getting it ca. 988 after 
Lechfeld.

I think your point about the later emperors seeking legitimacy is valid, 
but the idea that they considered themselves successors to Charlemagne 
is pretty ludicrous by the time Otto is on the scene.

Otto's crown, legitimized by Lechfeld, had a distinct character from the 
Carolingian Empire.

Otto was the first guy to TRULY shape the boundaries and culture of 
GERMANY, which was little more than an idea and dream at the time.  The 
Carolingians were, and saw themselves more as, a universal empire.

I also see your points about the connection through the word "Roman".  
However, I think you may be weighing it a bit too much.  Europe had changed 
by 988.  Charlemagne was a distant memory and his empire long fallen to 
pieces.
comments.author: TheLoyalOfficer

comments.text:
+TheLoyalOfficer There are plenty. I might only be able to refer to a few I 
gathered some years ago.
Keep in mind that none of the Holy Roman Emperors did refer to themselves 
as such. Their title was „Roman Emperor“ or „Emperor of the Romans“.
In the case of Charlemagne we would find terminology like „the first Roman 
emperor of the Germans“ or the like.

Here are a few quotes:

in the Kaiserchronik „chronicle of emperors“ from the 12th century:

"Karl der Pippînes sun, ... daz er der erste kaiser wart ze Rome von 
Diutisken landen.“
= „Charles, son of Pippin … that he was the first emperor of Rome from 
German lands.“

From Albrecht Dürer's famous painting of Charlemagne:

„Dìs ìſt der gſtalt und bìldnĭs gleích
kaìſer karlŭs der das Rømìſch reìch
Den teítſchen ŭnder tenìg macht
Seìn kron ŭnd klaìdŭng hoch geacht
ʒaıgt man ʒŭ Nŭrenberg alle Jar
Mit andern haĭtŭm offenbar“

=„This is in shape and likeness Emperor Charles, who subjected the Roman 
Empire to the Germans. His crown and clothing well esteemed is shown 
publicly in Nuremberg each year, along with other sanctuaries.",

In that painting Charlemagne is depicted wearing the regalia worn by the 
Holy Roman Emperors of his time.

A quote from "Geschichte der politischen Theorie in Deutschland 1300-2000" 
by Klaus von Beyme
concerning Alexander of Roes (1280-88)

"German clerics were confronted with the question why the pope had 
transfered the Roman empire to the German by crowning Charlemagne..."

Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa achieved the canonization of Charlemagne in 
order to legitimize his authority by having a saint as a founding figure of 
his empire.

And then there's the strong sense of tradition referring to Charlemagne 
such as the royal coronation in Aachen on the "Karlsthron" (throne of 
Charlemagne) and of course the imperial coronation by the pope in Rome.

Some of the Holy Roman Emperors like Henry III tried to legitimize their 
claim by stressing a relation to Charlemagne.

Charles IV was particularly devoted to Charlemagne and commissioned various 
sacred depictions of him like the famous Karlsbüste in Aachen.

And lastly, as I had mentioned, the numbering of kings begins with 
Charlemagne as Charles I --> Charles II (Charles the bold) --> Charles III 
(Charles the fat) --> Charles IV (Charles of Luxembourg) etc.
comments.author: MacX1985

comments.text:
+MacX1985 Which medieval sources refer to Charlemagne as the first Holy 
Roman Emperor?
comments.author: TheLoyalOfficer

comments.text:
+TheLoyalOfficer "Actually Charlemagne's empire split in THREE, hence the 
mess." true, I was making a time leap here.

"Yeah fine, prophesy and theology can cook up names, but I am referring to 
the de facto reality.  The HRE was not the Carolingian Empire.  That 
fragmented badly after Charlemagne's death."

It wasn't quite the same thing because in Carolingian times the kings 
didn't have to deal with other lords within their realm. But the essential 
thing was kept alive: the tradition of Roman emperorship bestowed on a 
Germanic king by the pope in Rome.
So, in that sense I would still argue that Charlemagne was the first Holy 
Roman Emperor.
Medieval chroniclers also said he was while they thought that Otto was 
special because he managed to attach the empire's dignity to the fate of 
the Germans. But afaik, no one thought he founded it.
comments.author: MacX1985

comments.text:
Actually Charlemagne's empire split in THREE, hence the mess.

I said *essentially* the kingdom of Germany.  Everyone had claims.  But the 
power centers were located in what we now call Germany, fragmented under 
the various Electors, etc.

Yeah fine, prophesy and theology can cook up names, but I am referring to 
the de facto reality.  The HRE was not the Carolingian Empire.  That 
fragmented badly after Charlemagne's death.

Then the Vikings started messing with everyone.
comments.author: TheLoyalOfficer

comments.text:
+TheLoyalOfficer "They are, quite simply, two completely separate and 
distinct states."
No, they really weren't. The kingdom of the Franks was one thing, the "Holy 
Roman Empire" was another one by definition.

The kingdom of the Franks split in two. Otto later sat on the throne of the 
Eastern part. A partition of the Frankish kingdom was quite common under 
the Merovingians. Eventually somebody would always reunite it at some 
point. The partition wasn't necessarily set in stone when Otto was king of 
East Francia. One of his successors, Henry II, was driven to reunite it 
again but there was just no way at this point.

 "Emperor of the West"  was not his title. He was "Imperator Romanorum" 
just as any of the medieval emperors until 1806 would call themselves.

"Oh the Germans knew it had ceased to exist!  Absolutely."

No. There was a reason why they came up with the title of the "Holy Roman 
Empire"... Medieval people believed that the world would come to an end 
after the empire of the Romans fell. It was because of a biblical prophecy 
in the book of Daniel that there would be 4 empires before the antichrist 
would arrive, the Roman one being the last of them which would become the 
ultimate Christian empire.

Thus people of the middle ages came up with the political theory of 
"translatio imperii" which said that the regency of the Roman empire could 
be transfered to other nations. It was believed that it went from the 
Romans to the Greeks and with the coronation of Charlemagne to the Franks 
or Germans.

You can't underestimate the role of Christian theology in the medieval 
mindset.

"The HRE was a lot more than propaganda.  It was essentially the Kingdom of 
Germany."

The Kingdom of Germany was one among many kingdoms that theoretically made 
up the HRE. The emperors never stopped claiming all of Italy for themselves 
no matter if they actually did have factual power there.
comments.author: MacX1985

comments.text:
They are, quite simply, two completely separate and distinct states.  Leo's 
little papal trick of crowning Charlemagne amounted to nothing.  "Emperor 
of the West" in 800 was just an attempt at the Impossible Dream, not the 
foundation of a new state.

Oh the Germans knew it had ceased to exist!  Absolutely.  And I would 
imagine that most of the Germans were not too excited about having 
the Western Roman Empire back.

Nor anyone else, for that matter.  25 year draft, broken-down corrupt 
bureaucracy and massive taxation?  No thanks!

Much later, Otto's victory at Lechfeld allowed for a military legitimacy 
that none of the other successor kings (ie Carolingians) had.  They were 
too busy murdering and going to war with each other.

The HRE was a lot more than propaganda.  It was essentially the Kingdom of 
Germany.  It's "neither Holy, nor Roman, nor an Empire" status came much 
later.
comments.author: TheLoyalOfficer

comments.text:
+TheLoyalOfficer The "Roman Empire" (to be more clear here) wasn't 
necessarily tied to any territory. It was just believed to never really 
have ceased to exist but was revived by Charlemagne. The emperor was 
thought to be the overlord of all of the Western (latin) kings. That was a 
theory that was certainly upheld until the late Middle Ages.
The emperor happened to be king of Germany from Otto the Great onwards but 
as the Carolingians showed that didn't necessarily needed to be the case. I 
believe there was even a French king after Otto who tried to invoke a claim 
to the imperial throne. I can't remember who just now...

Since the "Holy Roman Empire" was never more than propaganda to begin with, 
I find it arbitrary to make Otto the Great its founding figure. It was 
Charlemagne who caim up with the concept and who was invoked by every 
emperor following him.
Otto played a vital role in the development of the medieval German kingdom 
though.
comments.author: MacX1985

comments.text:
+MacX1985 The HRE did not have France.  It did not have many of the other 
territories of the Carolingian Empire.  The Carolingians are not the same 
as the HRE.
comments.author: TheLoyalOfficer

comments.text:
1.  Sure, Charlemagne was great.  But look at his successors!  Morons and 
fools!  Charles the Fat, Louis the Bald, Charles the Simple...  Too busy 
fighting each other than settling their differences and fighting the 
Vikings, Magyars, and Saracens effectively.

Yes, eventually Christianity prevailed, but at way too high of a cost.
comments.author: TheLoyalOfficer

comments.text:
+TheLoyalOfficer 1. How was it failed? Charlemagne is seen by most as the 
greatest and most powerful ruler of the Middle Ages. While Otto acted as a 
"primus inter pares" Charlemagne was the undisputed supreme leader of all 
of Europe.
It's no coincidence that everybody today knows who Charlemagne was while 
Otto is commonly known to a lesser extent and more connected to the 
emergence of medieval Germany.

2. Why would Otto be the "first" Holy Roman Emperor? That would necessarily 
mean he did anything first.

Was he the first of the medieval kings to be crowned Roman Emperor by the 
pope?
No, Charlemagne was. And after him 10 other emperors.

Was he the first king of East Francia?
No, that would be Louis the German, one of Charlemagne's grandsons.

Was he the first king of East Francia that happened to be crowned emperor?
No, that would be Charles III. And after him Arnulf of Carinthia.

Was he the first king to be elected by the dukes of East Francia instead of 
inheriting the thrown by birth right.
No, that was Conrad I.

Was he the first Saxon king of East Francia?
No, that was his father Henry I.

Finally a thing he did first:
He was the first Saxon king of East Francia that was also crowned emperor 
by the pope. But dynasties in the HRE changed regularly.

Otto didn't regard himself as anything different than Charlemagne's 
successor. He was crowned king in Charlemagne's favorite palatinate in 
Aachen where he wore traditional Frankish clothing. When he took the 
Italian crown he styled himself as "Rex Francorum et Langobardum" same as 
Charlemagne and finally took on the same imperial title.

If the HRE started with Otto you would expect him to be listed as their 
first king or emperor but medieval kings' lists don't exclude Charlemagne 
or any of the other Carolingians. He remains "Charles I." The first 
non-Carolingian ruler named Charles was Charles IV of Luxembourg. The first 
non-Carolingian Louis was Louis IV "the Bavarian".
comments.author: MacX1985

comments.text:
+MacX1985 Because it was.  Pope Leo crown Charlemagne Emperor of the West, 
NOT Holy Roman Emperor.

This was a (failed) attempt to resurrect the Roman Empire which had fallen 
in 476.

comments.text:
The Carolingian Empire is not really the same entity as the Holy Roman 
Empire that Charles V ruled. The Carolingian Empire ended when 
Charlemagne's descendents fractured the empire with their fighting over who 
should rule. A German named Otto is the real founder of the HRE.﻿
comments.author: ObadiahtheSlim

comments.text:
I often hear that but I don't really know why people would bring that up. 
Basically there are two different things: The Frankish kingdom, a factual 
feudal state that existed since the days of Clovis; and the "Holy Roman 
Empire", a theological concept made up by Charlemagne and pope Leo III.

The Frankish kingdom broke apart in the early 10th century, at the very 
least when there where non-Carolingian kings in both the Western and 
Eastern part who mutually agreed that the respective other one would 
furthermore rule in their kingdoms.

After Charlemagne there have been 10 other ones who wore the imperial Roman 
crown, beginning with his son Louis the Pious, the last one was Berengar of 
Friuli.
Then after some years Otto the great was crowned emperor but it wasn't 
really anything new besides him being a Saxon and not a Frank anymore.
Medieval chroniclers always mention Charlemagne as their first emperor. 
Otto gets mentioned when stating that he brought the imperial dignity on to 
the Germans.
comments.author: MacX1985
